items.title: Enable pickling of MultiDictProxy objects
items.body:
As an aiohttp user, I would like MultiDictProxy and CIMultiDictProxy objects to be pickle-able so that I can cache aiohttp.ClientResponseErrors to disk and/or use aiohttp with multiprocessing.

Currently, attempting to pickle MultiDictProxy instances produces the following error:
```python
>>> import pickle
>>> import multidict
>>> d = multidict.MultiDict(a=1, b=2, c=3)
>>> p = multidict.MultiDictProxy(d)
>>> pickle.dumps(p)
TypeError: can't pickle multidict._multidict.MultiDictProxy objects
```
Attempting to pickle a CIMultDictProxy instance produces a similar error, thus preventing their use in scenarios that require pickling, such as on-disk caching and multiprocessing, just to name a couple that I am actually using.

I believe the alternative is to use custom Pickler classes and/or monkeypatch modules to convert the proxy objects into MultiDict or CIMultDict objects, which do support pickling.

items.title: Silenced error in __getitem__ when compare with a mapping
items.body:
The following code
```python
from multidict import MultiDict
from collections.abc import Mapping

class BadMapping(Mapping):
    def __getitem__(self, key):
        1 / 0
    def __iter__(self):
        yield "a"
    def __len__(self):
        return 1

print(MultiDict(a=1) == BadMapping())
```
silences the exception and prints
```
False
```
This can cause returning wrong result when evaluation of `__getitem__` was interrupted by an unexpected error like KeyboardInterrupt or MemoryError.

items.title: SystemError when compare with a mapping with broken length
items.body:
The following code:
```python
from multidict import MultiDict
from collections.abc import Mapping

class BadMapping(Mapping):
    def __getitem__(self, key):
        return 1
    def __iter__(self):
        yield "a"
    def __len__(self):
        1 / 0

print(MultiDict(a=1) == BadMapping())
```
causes raising a SystemError:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 7, in __len__
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
SystemError: <built-in method write of _io.TextIOWrapper object at 0x7f7d26f71d70> returned a result with an error set
```

items.title: Errors in MultiDict constructor and update with non-mapping and keyword arguments
items.body:
If pass a list argument and keyword arguments to MultiDict constructor, it will be modified:
```
>>> from multidict import MultiDict
>>> arg = [('a', 1)]
>>> MultiDict(arg, b=2)
<MultiDict('a': 1, 'b': 2)>
>>> arg
[('a', 1), ('b', 2)]
```
If pass other non-mapping as a positional argument and keyword arguments to MultiDict constructor, it causes a SystemError:
```
>>> arg = (('a', 1),)
>>> MultiDict(arg, b=2)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
SystemError: ../Objects/listobject.c:307: bad argument to internal function
```

There is a similar bug in the update method.

multidict 4.7.4

Seems that multidict 4.7.x is leaking, that only happens when I iterate over multidict instance

Please check following code snippet:
```python
import gc
import multidict
import objgraph

print("Multidict:", multidict.__version__)
objgraph.growth() # save current objects state

```

```
MultiDict        1        +1

```

3.8.1

4.7.3

```python
import gc
import multidict

print("Multidict:", multidict.__version__)

gc.collect()
before = len(gc.get_objects())
for i in range(5):

```

items.title: istrs preserve the capitalisation, contrary to the documentation
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Per the [documentation](https://multidict.readthedocs.io/en/stable/multidict.html#istr), `multidict.istr` is a title-cased string, and `istr("STRING")` is `"String"` internally. However since the recent merging of #387, this is no longer the case: the capitalisation is preserved instead.

**To Reproduce**

    > python3 -c 'import multidict; print(repr(multidict.istr("STRING")))'

**Expected behaviour, and actual behaviour up to version 4.5.2**

    "String"

**Actual behaviour since version 4.6.0**

    "STRING"

**Your version of the Python**
3.6.9

**Your version of the multidict distribution**
4.6.0, 4.6.1, and 4.7.0

**Additional context**
In addition to the behaviour contradicting the documentation, this brings back aiohttp bugs https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/813 and https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/934.

items.title: MultiDict class construction regression
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

With multidict 4.7.0, you cannot create a MultiDict with an iterable of key-valu data.

**To Reproduce**   

```
>>> import sys
>>> import multidict
>>> multidict.__version__
'4.7.0'
>>> sys.version
'3.7.3 (default, Apr 20 2019, 14:54:00) \n[GCC 7.3.0]'
>>> headers=[['User-Agent', 'HTTP Stuff']]
# This is a valid input for the python dict() function
>>> foo = dict(headers)
>>> foo
{'User-Agent': 'HTTP Stuff'}
# Direct MultiDict use failse
>>> multidict.MultiDict(headers)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: MultiDict keys should be either str or subclasses of str
# aiohttp uses CiMultiDict
>>> multidict.CIMultiDict(headers)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: CIMultiDict keys should be either str or subclasses of str
```

**Expected behavior**

I expect to make a CIMultiDict / MultiDict with the input list of items.

**Logs/tracebacks**

Included in the above example.

**Your version of the Python**

3.7.3 compiled via pyenv on ubuntu 18.04

**Your version of the multidict distribution**

4.7.0

**Additional context**

I ran into this with testing aiohttp related calls where headers were being passed as a list of key, value pairs.

aiohttp typedefs their header arguments with a struct they call LooseHeaders defined here https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/blob/v3.6.2/aiohttp/typedefs.py#L42

their docs refer to header arguments as either dicts or list of key/valu pairs https://aiohttp.readthedocs.io/en/stable/client_reference.html#client-session

That is passed into the multidict struct here https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/blob/v3.6.2/aiohttp/client.py#L827

This is valid according to the multidict documentation here:

https://multidict.readthedocs.io/en/stable/multidict.html#multidict

Specifically the line `Accepted parameters are the same as for dict.`. This is no longer valid with the 4.7.0 release.

items.title: CIMultiDict can not be subclassed
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
`CIMultiDict` can not be subclassed because the type definition does not have the  `Py_TPFLAGS_BASETYPE` flag set.

https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/blob/d786088778285ba56e06c992f44e546fb4c7b74b/multidict/_multidict.c#L1002-L1007
https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/blob/d786088778285ba56e06c992f44e546fb4c7b74b/multidict/_multidict.c#L1337-L1342

**To Reproduce**   
The following code fails with `TypeError: type 'multidict._multidict.CIMultiDict' is not an acceptable base type`

```
from multidict import CIMultiDict

class Header(CIMultiDict):
    pass
```

**Expected behavior**
`CIMultiDict` should be subclassable like `MultiDict `

**Your version of the Python**
3.6 and 3.7

**Your version of the multidict distribution**
4.7.0

items.title: Use the single .c file for all multidict code
items.body:
Pushing everything into the single compilation unit makes the generated code more optimized.

While gcc/clang supports `-flto` flag and Microsoft compiler has own option for it, the LTO optimization looks tricky, at least CPython doesn't use it by default.

Instead, CPython has `./Objects/stringlib` -- a folder with header files that implements different aspects of the very complex string type. All these headers are included in the corresponding `.c` files.

We should do the same for multidict probably: make `multidict/_multilib` folder, push almost all code into this folder, `#include _multilib/feature.h` in `multidict/_multidict.c`.

I expect that we can get inlining of all `pair_list_*` functions by this at least.

items.title: Support MultiDict[str] generic in runtime
items.body:
Currently, it produces a runtime error because the *class object* is not subscribable.

The fix can be implemented in two ways:
1. Provide a metaclass for multidict classes with `__getitem__` implemented.
2. Support `__class_getitem__`.

The later doesn't require metaclass but works on Python 3.7+.  
Perhaps that's fine, old Python versions lose the popularity and eventually will pass away.

items.title: RuntimeWarning on Python 3.8
items.body:
**Description**
Attempting to import multidict using Python ~~3.8.0a4~~ ~~3.8.0b1 raises a SystemError~~ 3.8.0b2 causes a RuntimeWarning to occur.

**Reproduction Steps**
1. Use Python ~~3.8.0a4~~ ~~3.8.0b1~~ 3.8.0b2
2. `import multidict`
3. Observe ~~traceback~~ warning

**Expected Behavior**
~~Successful import~~
No warning

**Traceback**
```
>>> import multidict
<frozen importlib._bootstrap>:219: RuntimeWarning: builtins.type size changed, may indicate binary incompatibility. Expected 864 from C header, got 880 from PyObject
```
~~Traceback (most recent call last):~~
  ~~File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>~~
  ~~File "C:\Program Files\Python38\lib\site-packages\multidict\__init__.py", line 23, in <module>~~
    ~~from ._multidict import (MultiDictProxy,~~
~~SystemError: c:\_work\14\s\objects\codeobject.c:131: bad argument to internal function~~

**Python Version**
~~Python 3.8.0a4 (v3.8.0a4:c1004b8546, May  7 2019, 13:53:12) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32~~
~~Python 3.8.0b1 (tags/v3.8.0b1:3b5deb0116, Jun  4 2019, 19:52:55) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32~~
Python 3.8.0b2 (tags/v3.8.0b2:21dd01d, Jul  4 2019, 16:00:09) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32

**multidict Version**
multidict 4.5.2

**Additional Context**
This seems to be caused by changes to `PyCode_New` as part of the implementation of [PEP 570](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0570/):
https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/8c77b8cb9188165a123f2512026e3629bf03dc9b#diff-e3862c228cffe90385cf9f14529868fe (https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/12701)

[bpo-37221](https://bugs.python.org/issue37221) has reverted `PyCode_New` to be a backwards compatible wrapper for a new `PyCode_NewEx` with https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/cb083f7cdf604c1d9d264f387f9e8846bc953eb3 (https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/13959, https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/14505).
The handling for this change was added in Cython 0.29.11 with https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/9b6a02f7f28934fa0d02ab4d173c1b89bf3bd8f8 (https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3009) and fixed in Cython 0.29.12 with https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/0d88839168013fd69350d31eaee5514cd2f727b9 (https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3031, https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3034).

Updating to Cython 0.29.12 should now resolve this issue.

items.title: Request headers do not preserve case defined in aiohttp.headers
items.body:
## Long story short

Some servers such as `lighttpd/1.4.41` do not ignore case in headers. It will reply with a `400 Bad Request` when the case is not as expected.

See also related https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/1570

## Expected behaviour

I do a `session.ws_connect(url, ssl=ssl_ctx)` and expect the header case to be as defined in `aiohttp.headers`:
```
SEC_WEBSOCKET_VERSION = istr('Sec-WebSocket-Version')
SEC_WEBSOCKET_PROTOCOL = istr('Sec-WebSocket-Protocol')
```

## Actual behaviour

The headers get changed (note how `Sec-WebSocket-Version` changes to `Sec-Websocket-Version`
```
(Pdb++) real_headers
`<CIMultiDict('Upgrade': 'websocket', 'Connection': 'Upgrade', 'Sec-Websocket-Version': '13', 'Sec-Websocket-Key': 'MYmdoh4JaSjgMbXLyexeFg==')>
```

Please note how this is caused by istr:
```
(Pdb++) aiohttp.hdrs.istr('Sec-WebSocket-Version')
'Sec-Websocket-Version'
```

## Steps to reproduce
```
async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
    ssl_ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
    ssl_ctx.check_hostname = False
    ssl_ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
    ws = await session.ws_connect(url, ssl=ssl_ctx)
```

## Your environment

```
Python 3.6.7
aiohttp==3.5.4

Linux me.domain.net 4.1.12-124.18.6.el6uek.x86_64 aio-libs/aiohttp#2 SMP Wed Aug 15 19:15:35 PDT 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 18.10
Release:	18.10
Codename:	cosmic
```

items.title: multidict 4.5 memory leak
items.body:
It seems like the [recent version](https://github.com/aio-libs/multidict/pull/275) of multidict brakes aiohttp somehow.

Server:

```python
from aiohttp import web

async def hello(request):
    return web.json_response(await request.json())

app = web.Application()
app.add_routes([web.post('/', hello)])
web.run_app(app)
```

Client:

```python
import asyncio
import aiohttp

async def foo(times):
    data = {'foo': 1}
    async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
        for x in range(times):
            resp = await session.post('http://localhost:8080', json=data)
            if not x % 100:
                print(await resp.json())

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(foo(100000))
loop.close()
```

Just after 100000 cycles this simple server takes 171M of ram and doesn't release it.
4.4.2 works like a charm.

python 3.6.4
aiohttp 3.4.4 but should affect other versions `multidict>=4.0,<5.0`

items.title: How to get original casing for key?
items.body:
I'm writing a Discord bot that notifies users when certain words are said in chat.
The highlight words are case insensitive.
Currently, I'm using a `CIMultiDict` to map highlight word -> user who subscribes to that highlight word.
Like this:
`<CIMultiDict('abc': 123, 'ABC': 456, 'abc': 789)>`
This means that when 'abc' is said in chat, users 123, 456, and 789 will be notified.

I want to notify users 123 and 789 that they were highlighted because they subscribed to "abc",
but I want to notify user 789 that they were highlighted because they subscribed to "ABC".

How can I do this?

items.title: multidict 4.4.1 not compatible with Python 3.4
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
multidict 4.4.1 isn't compatible with Python 3.4 - you can't import it in Python 3.4.

**To Reproduce**

- Create a Python 3.4 virtual environment in any convenient way.
- Run `pip install multidict==4.4.1`
- In a Python REPL, execute the code: `import multidict` and observe an `ImportError`

**Expected behavior**
No `ImportError` when importing `multidict` and ability to use it in Python 3.4.

**Logs/tracebacks**
Example Python REPL dialog:
```
>>> import multidict
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/dan/apps/miniconda/miniconda3/4.4.10/envs/api/lib/python3.4/site-packages/multidict/__init__.py", line 18, in <module>
    from ._abc import MultiMapping, MutableMultiMapping
  File "/home/dan/apps/miniconda/miniconda3/4.4.10/envs/api/lib/python3.4/site-packages/multidict/_abc.py", line 3, in <module>
    from typing import (Mapping, MutableMapping, List, Union, Iterable,
ImportError: No module named 'typing'
```

**Your version of the Python**
```
>>> import sys
>>> sys.version_info
sys.version_info(major=3, minor=4, micro=5, releaselevel='final', serial=0)
```

**Your version of the multidict distribution**
4.4.1

Create a separate GitHub App for doing deployments to PYPI [actually it's for all aio-libs]

I want to listen to Deployment events from this service, while Deployments themselves should be fired by CI services (Travis, AppVeyor etc.).

The idea is to use this service as a synchronization primitive and publish all wheels simultaneously, so that there won't be any time lag between different architecture-specific wheels appearing on PYPI.

I'm currently experimenting with this.

Ref: https://github.com/Scifabric/deployments

items.title: Support PEP-561
items.body: [PEP-561](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0561/) enables package maintainers to distribute their typing stub files and have mypy (as of version 0.590) use them from the installed package. Since multidict already includes stub files, the only thing that needs to be done is to distribute a file named `py.typed` in the package directory.

items.title: Cython and Python versions of CIMultiDict treat key case differently
items.body:
First noticed this in 3.3.2 (probably existed before that), still exists in 4.0.0:

As one would expect (IMO) the Cython version uses the title-ized key for matching and preserves the original key for output/serialization. The Python version throws away the original key completely and uses the title-ized key for both purposes, breaking output. Again, that's my opinion, but in any case, the behavior should be the same.

```python
In [1]: from multidict._multidict import CIMultiDict  # Cython

In [2]: md = CIMultiDict()
   ...: md['some_key'] = 1
   ...: list(md.items())
   ...:
Out[2]: [('some_key', 1)]  # outputs original key

In [3]: from multidict._multidict_py import CIMultiDict  # Python

In [4]: md = CIMultiDict()
   ...: md['some_key'] = 1
   ...: list(md.items())
   ...:
Out[4]: [('Some_Key', 1)]  # outputs title-ized key
```

items.title: Large lag between Windows and Linux/OS X PyPI uploads
items.body:
Hi!

Similar to the issues experienced with aiohttp (eg aio-libs/aiohttp#2347), there is a massive delay (currently 3 hours, but the other releases are still outstanding) between the Windows wheel for a new multidict release being uploaded to PyPI, and when the sdist/other wheels (manylinux/OS X) are available.

This is problematic, since tooling such as pyup.io see the new release in the PyPI feed, and so open a PR to update the dependency. However at that point only the Windows wheel exists, causing the Travis run to fail (eg mozilla/treeherder#2899).

For possible solutions, see:
https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/2347#issuecomment-337875769

Many thanks :-)

items.title: Guard iterations
items.body: Iteration over keys, items and values should raise `RuntimeError` if dict is changed.

items.title: Need to rewrite cython extensions in pure C
items.body:
The reason is `multidict.add(key, val)` is ten times slower than `dict[key] = val`.

This is because multidict stores data internally as a list of cythonized `_Item` objects.
But creation of python (ever cythonized) object is too expensive for our use case.

The solution is using C structs for internal data but Cython has no support for visiting values stored in these structures: `tp_visit` and `tp_clear` slots.

Thus for sake of speed we need pure C implementation.

items.title: `pop()` is inconsistent
items.body:
It now removes all keys but returns the last value
Should remove only first key.

`pop()` should be an alias for new method `.popone()` to mimic `get/getone`.

items.title: Replace istr()
items.body:
Deriving from `str` is too expensive.
We need fast and simple way to figure out is key already titled (canonized) or not.

The alternative could be `multidict.canonize(s: str) -> str` function.
It converts parameter to `s.title()`, intern it by `sys.intern(...)` call and store the result into global dictionary.
Thus we have a very fast check for  canonized strings.

The drawback or proposal is the canonized strings are never deleted (I think it's fine for `aiohttp.hdrs` usage). All `canonize()` calls should be done on module import stage, that's why I propose a new function  instead of adding new tricks to `istr`.

`istr` will be supported for years anyway but `canonize` is the only way to keep multidicts fast.
Right now `istr` calls is 10-25% slower on `MultiDict` -- its not acceptable (but it's still much faster on `CIMultiDict` lookups than plain `str`).

items.title: Force keys to str instances
items.body:
Right now a key type is dark corner: it could be str, istr or something other.
For sake of further optimizations it should be `str` always.

Passing `istr` as key to any miltidict API is still allowed and encouraged: it saves execution time by getting rid of `s.title()` conversion.

But `istr` type is ambiguous by it nature: we can define equality for `str` and `istr` by comparing their *canonical* representations but ordering is cumbersome.
Ordering by canonical reprs leads to very tricky errors, the same for *original* reprs.
Also CPython is very optimized for `str` but not classes derived from it.

I believe the change doesn't touch our users but aiohttp might get speedup on implementing the issue.

items.title: Implement dict's version
items.body: It could speedup headers caching

items.title: Implement `.popall(key[, default])`
items.body: Should remove all key occurrences and return a list with all removed values.

items.title: Multidicts does not preserve order on update
items.body:
When updating existing key in multidict, it is moved to the end (original order is not preserved):
```
>>> d = CIMultiDict()
>>> d['1'] = '2'
>>> d['3'] = '4'
>>> d
<CIMultiDict('1': '2', '3': '4')>
>>> d['1'] = '10'
>>> d
<CIMultiDict('3': '4', '1': '10')>
```
In above example, guarantee of preserving insertion order should leave existing key `'1'` on its original first position.

items.title: Multidict preserves order- document it somewhere
items.body:
As it is implemented now, Multidict preserves order.
Because of the way it is used in aiohttp (parsing post items and HTTP headers), this seems a very desirable property, and not merely an implementation detail.

I think it should be documented both here and in aiohttp's docs that Multidict preserves order, so that one doesn't need to read the implementation to be sure.

items.title: multidict._multidict.so is not distributable
items.body:
with gdb
```
Program received signal SIGILL, Illegal instruction.
0x00007ffff00b34aa in PyInit__multidict () from /opt/spot4/bin/lib/python3.6/multidict._multidict.so

```

I moved cx_freezed code to fresh installed debian. `ldd` has no missed libs. But there is this trouble.

After deleting it All other libs loaded successfully. And previous version of aiohttp works well after moving.

items.title: different tag name for 2.1.4
items.body: Usually you use `v` prefix, but not in 2.1.4. Mistake or plan for further releases?

items.title: no tar-ball or zip on pypi
items.body:
Hi

would be great, if a tar-ball could be made available on pypi (useful for, e.g. linux distributions for creating a package). https://pypi.python.org/pypi/multidict currently only has whl packages.

Thanks

Arun

items.title: `MultiDict.copy()` doesn't work with `istr` keys
items.body:
Here's a small test case:

```
>>> import multidict
>>> m=multidict.CIMultiDict({multidict.istr('Foo'): 'bar'})
>>> m.copy()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "multidict/_multidict.pyx", line 325, in multidict._multidict.MultiDict.copy (multidict/_multidict.c:6830)
  File "multidict/_multidict.pyx", line 251, in multidict._multidict.MultiDict.__init__ (multidict/_multidict.c:5495)
  File "multidict/_multidict.pyx", line 289, in multidict._multidict.MultiDict._extend (multidict/_multidict.c:6115)
TypeError: Expected str, got istr
```

`MultiDict._extend` expects every key to be a str. `aiohttp.hdrs`creates `istr` objects, so `request.headers.copy()` doesn't work.
